abstract.p: Federal Communications Commission, responding to complaints from two Democratic senators, launches investigation into Republican presidential campaign television commercial on Medicare which contains word 'rats,' to determine whether it used subliminal advertising techniques (S)

block.p: Responding to complaints from two Democratic senators, the Federal Communications Commission has begun an investigation into a Republican campaign television commercial to determine whether it used subliminal advertising techniques.

On Friday, the commission sent letters to 217 television stations that may have broadcast the advertisement, which was produced by the Republican National Committee. The stations have until next Friday to respond.

Responding to complaints from two Democratic senators, the Federal Communications Commission has begun an investigation into a Republican campaign television commercial to determine whether it used subliminal advertising techniques.

On Friday, the commission sent letters to 217 television stations that may have broadcast the advertisement, which was produced by the Republican National Committee. The stations have until next Friday to respond.

The commercial criticizes Vice President Al Gore's proposal to add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare, saying that the plan would let ''bureaucrats decide'' what coverage Medicare participants receive. As the word ''bureaucrats'' flashes across the screen, the word ''rats'' appears in large type for a moment.

In the letters, Charles W. Kelley, chief of the investigations and hearings division of the commission's enforcement bureau, asked whether any of the stations' officers, directors or employees knew before the commercial was broadcast that it contained the word ''rats.''

The agency has no power to sanction political campaigns or producers of advertisements. But it can send a letter of admonishment or even revoke the license of a station that knowingly broadcasts an advertisement the agency deems unfairly deceptive.
Subliminal messages, Mr. Kelley wrote, ''clearly are intended to be deceptive.''
